newsitem.title: USA: U.S. state budgets in healthy condition.
newsitem.headline: U.S. state budgets in healthy condition.

text.p: No U.S. state registered a budget deficit at the end of fiscal 1996, making their finances the healthiest since 1980, the magazine State Legislatures said on Tuesday.
But the publication of the Denver-based National Conference of State Legislatures said the outlook for 1997 is not so rosy.

"The aggregate year-end balance for fiscal year 1997 is projected to fall to 4.7 percent (as a percentage of general fund expenditures)," the article said. "Furthermore fewer states expect to end the fiscal year with balances exceeding five percent," the magazine said based.
The aggregate balance for FY 1996 stood at 5.8 percent.
"On the bright side, no state expects FY 1997 with a deficit," the magazine said in an article based on the organization's annual survey of state budget and tax actions.
A handful of states expect revenues to drop below last year's collections, either because of sluggish economies or previously enacted tax cuts.
States expect to spend less on Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) and to keep Medicaid spending in check, due in part to good economic conditions.
But spending on corrections has been one of the fastest growing areas of state budgets in recent years and are expected to grow 6.8 percent over fiscal 1996 levels.
Because of favorable economic conditions spending on higher education is projected to grow 5.1 percent in FY 1997, its largest percentage increase since the last 1980s, the magazine said.
